results.title: Australian gazette. No. 3
results.brief_description: This reel consists of 7 magazine items, including snapshots of the Fitzroy Gardens, a trip to Seal Rock by boat, Kangaroos at Wilson’s Prom, beehives shot in close-up and some prize footage of a motorcycle race on a track around the outside of the Exhibition Buildings. There is also some surprising early experimental filming of Flinders Street, and traffic and crowds on Swanston Street. One amazing shot appears upside-down and then mid-way proceeds to turn upright and show the traffic and people travelling backwards. Footage is then sped up for a cable car ride down a main street. No credits available.

results.title: Beneath Roads
results.creator_credit: Jenna Warwick, Rah Dakota and Field Carr
results.material_description:
mutli-channel, colour, black and white, sound
9 min 7 sec
results.brief_description:
Beneath Roads is a response to a purposeful void in Australia’s collective knowledge. Long before horses and carts found their way across the country, the land was crisscrossed by Indigenous pathways that remain the foundation for countless highways and roadways today.

Knowledge of these routes, their features and cultural significance is depicted in songs, which are memorised and passed down through generations. These traditional forms of navigation and spiritual understanding of place are known as Songlines. Many of the roads you drive on today are the result of this practice. One of the most identifiable pathways in Victoria navigated for centuries is the Omeo highway connecting north-east Victoria to Gippsland through Ngarigo, Jaitmatang and Gunnai Kurnai Country.

This visual poem ruminates on the layering of bitumen over these ancient routes through the lens of Australian cinema. The portrayal of the outback on screen has become one of this nation’s most recognisable cultural exports and the road genre offers one way to unpack a constructed national identity.

ABOUT THE SOURCES

Beneath Roads is assembled from a range of different film sources.

Ivan Sen’s debut feature, the road film Beneath Clouds (2002), considers the unresolved tensions of settler Australia. As two Indigenous teenagers, Vaughn (Damien Pitt) and Lena (Dannielle Hall), hitchhike toward Sydney, their journey is defined more by racism than the freedom that the road often symbolises. Director of photography Allan Collins captures the landscape as one hemmed in by powerlines and overcast skies, the terrain patrolled by cops and trampled by industry. But despite these settler interventions, the beauty and grandeur of Country prospers, captured through wide vistas and intimate close-ups of the landscape. Both Sen and Collins won an AACTA award for Best Director and Best Cinematography respectively.

Beneath Clouds and other narrative titles are juxtaposed with archival historical films about Australian road building. These Government-made promotional films of the 1950s and 60s were used to build support for ‘nation building’ and were released during the same period First Peoples gained the right to vote in 1962. These are included in Beneath Roads to highlight the lack of awareness of centuries-old Indigenous navigation and travel routes upon which many modern roads were built.

Beneath Roads further counters this lack of awareness by including footage of the Southern Warriors, a Victorian Aboriginal motorcycle club. On Survival Day in 2024, the Southern Warriors rode to Coranderrk mission to honour Wurundjeri activist William Barak’s historic protest walks from Coranderrk to Melbourne, during which Barak advocated for the mission and his people’s rights. Historically First Peoples’ ability to travel was restricted by systemic racism and discriminatory government policies that pervaded Australia until the 1970s. The Southern Warriors stand in stark contrast to this history, representing a sense of freedom, safety and pride for Indigenous communities. Impossible to ignore, the self-described ‘warriors’ travel the state Black, loud and proud.

results.title: British Mutoscope featuring Charlie Chaplin reel
results.brief_description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope.

constellations_primary.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_primary.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

results.description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
description_for_label: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.

results.title: lifeSigns: eco-system of signs and symbols
results.material_description: video, interactive software, computers, monitors, projection, PVC stands, colour and audio
results.brief_description: An interactive digital networked work where participants play selected emotions as game identities in any manner they choose, the results seen in a fluid projection onto a mounted floor screen between the game terminals in the form of a dynamic and fluctuating virtual realm. Through playing the game, then, the participant contributes to building an ecosystem of sentiments at play and in conflict with one another. The ‘life signs’ chosen by participants are generated as three dimensional icons that construct an evolving virtual language of symbols, sounds and behaviours in interaction with the audiences’ collective participation. The floor projection represents the fluctuating results of the networked game, while an immersive soundscape simultaneously responds to the ever-changing game narrative.The more participants, the greater the intensity of image and sound. The process of the audiences use of and play with sentiments and emotions thus becomes the foundation in constant flux for the visual and aural world that the audience engages with in the installation.

results.title: The Man Who Fell to Earth
results.creator_credit: Nicolas Roeg, Barry Spikings, Michael Deeley and British Lion Films
results.brief_description: David Bowie, plays The Stranger. Armed with a British passport, he arrives in New York but is in fact an alien from a dying planet, having studied earth habits from monitoring television. This hairless, sexless creature is eventually caught and handed over to a team of scientists and doctors for research. Nicolas Roeg’s technical brilliance is apparent in this weirdly voyeuristic science fiction fantasy which is at times emeshed in its convoluted plot. Co-starring Buck Henry as a patent lawyer who befriends The Stranger and reaps success from the acquaintance and Rip Torn as Professor Nathan Brycce, determined to discover the truth.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nicolas Roeg, Barry Spikings, Michael Deeley and British Lion Films
results.description:
“David Bowie’s journey from a heartbroken alien trapped on earth to a powerful and wealthy entrepreneur is a mad and imaginative ride that is as relevant as ever.” – filmmaker and The Future & Other Fictions advisory group member Robert Connolly.

David Bowie, plays The Stranger. Armed with a British passport, he arrives in New York but is in fact an alien from a dying planet, having studied earth habits from monitoring television. This hairless, sexless creature is eventually caught and handed over to a team of scientists and doctors for research. Nicolas Roeg’s technical brilliance is apparent in this weirdly voyeuristic science fiction fantasy which is at times emeshed in its convoluted plot. Co-starring Buck Henry as a patent lawyer who befriends The Stranger and reaps success from the acquaintance and Rip Torn as Professor Nathan Brycce, determined to discover the truth.

results.title: The Left Hand of Darkness
results.description:
“A controversial novel that remains a provocative vision of a future built on the value and need for empathy to move civilisation forward.” – filmmaker and The Futures & Other Fictions advisory group member Robert Connolly.

Ursula K. Le Guin’s The Left Hand of Darkness (1969) is a groundbreaking work of speculative fiction, often celebrated for its exploration of gender, politics, and culture. Set on the icy planet Gethen, or “Winter,” the story follows Genly Ai, an envoy from an interplanetary alliance called the Ekumen, who seeks to bring Gethen into this collective.

Gethen’s inhabitants are androgynous, adopting male or female characteristics only during a brief period of sexual activity known as kemmer. This unique biology challenges Genly’s assumptions about gender roles and relationships, forcing him to confront his own biases. The book delves deeply into how gender shapes societal structures, communication, and power dynamics, making it a thought-provoking reflection on our own world.

The story’s heart lies in the evolving relationship between Genly and Estravan, a Gethenian politician who risks everything to support Genly’s mission. Their journey across Gethen’s frozen wastelands is both a physical trial and a test of trust, exploring themes of loyalty, connection, and understanding across cultural divides.

Le Guin crafts a vivid, immersive world, using Gethen’s climate and customs to highlight the fragility and resilience of humanity. By blending science fiction with anthropological insight, The Left Hand of Darkness invites readers to question their perspectives on identity, community, and the nature of human connection. It remains a timeless classic, as relevant today as it was upon its release.

results.title: Underground : Tales of Hacking, Madness and Obsession on the Electronic Frontier
results.title_for_label: Underground : Tales of Hacking, Madness and Obsession on the Electronic Frontier
results.description:
Suelette Dreyfus’ investigation of the early years of computer hacking, largely here in Melbourne, captures the philosophical foundation that saw a young Julian Assange lay the foundation for Wikileaks.

Buy or download the book on underground.net.
description_for_label:
Suelette Dreyfus’ investigation of the early years of computer hacking, largely here in Melbourne, captures the philosophical foundation that saw a young Julian Assange lay the foundation for Wikileaks.

Buy or download the book on underground.net.

results.title: La Jetee
results.brief_description: Set in Paris after the Third World War; an imprisoned man is being used by scientists to investigate time travel. He is haunted by a childhood memory of the pier at Orly Airport, a woman’s face, a man’s death. The fiction is constructed through still photographs. Photographs - images of the past - thus replace moving images with their power to create the illusion of the present. Script by Catherine Varlin, Chris Marker.
results.description:
“A heartbreaking love story that uses still images to entwine the past, present and future in a time-travelling masterpiece.” – filmmaker and The Futures & Other Fictions advisory group member Robert Connolly

Set in Paris after the Third World War; an imprisoned man is being used by scientists to investigate time travel. Photographs - images of the past - thus replace moving images with their power to create the illusion of the present. Script by Catherine Varlin, Chris Marker.
